question: How are you, Keaton?
answer: I'd have to say my spine was broken, Keyser.

question: Ready?
answer: What time is it?

question: Number two. Step forward. KNOCK IT OFF. Get back in line.
answer: It was bullshit. The whole rap was a setup. Everything is the cops' fault. You don't put guys like that in a room together. Who knows what can happen?

question: Are you done?
answer: They drilled us all night. Somebody was pissed about that truck getting knocked off and the cops had nothing. They were hoping somebody would slip. Give them something to go on. They knew we wouldn't fight it because they knew how to lean on us. They'd been doing it forever. Our rights went right out the window. It was a violation. I mean disgraceful. They went after McManus first. He was a good guy. Crazy though. A top notch entry man .

question: So where'd you dump the truck? The truck with the guns, fucko. Right here. Suck it out. You want to know what your buddy Fenster told us? WHERE'S THE FUCKING TRUCK?
answer: I want to call my lawyer. I don;'t know about any truck. I was in Connecticut all night on Friday.

question: That's not what McManus said.
answer: Who?

question: Be fold us about the truck.
answer: Hey, are we talking about the same thing?

question: I'll charge you when I'm ready.
answer: with what?

question: You know damn well, dead-man.
answer: Hey, that was your mistake, not mine. Did you ever think to ask me? I've been

question: What's that? The restaurant business? Not anymore From now on you're in the getting-fucked-by-us business . I'm gonna make you famous, cocksucker.
answer: Like I said. It was all your mistake. Charge me with it and I'll beat it. Let's get back to the truck.

question: Somebody should do something. What is this shit - getting hauled in every five minutes? Okay, so I did a little time, does that mean I get railed every time a truck finds its way off the planet?
answer: These guys got no probable cause.

question: You're fuckin' A right, no P.C. Well screw P.C. No right. No goddamn right. You do some time, they never let you go. Treat me like a criminal, I'll end up a criminal.
answer: You are a criminal.

question: I'd say you've gotten on his main and central nerve, McManus.
answer: Do your friend a favor, Fenster, keep him quiet .

question: Forget him. It's not important. I was trying to make a point.
answer: This whole thing was a shakedown. How many times have you been in a line- up? It's always you and four dummies. The P.D. pays homeless guys ten bucks a head half the time. No way they'd line five felons in the same row. No way. And what the hell is a voice line-.up? A public defender could get you off of that.

question: So why the hell was I hauled in and cavity searched tonight?
answer: It was the Feds. A truck load of guns gets snagged, Customs comes down on N.Y.P.D. for some answers - they come up with us. They're grabbing at straws. It's politics - nothing you can do.

question: I don't want to know.
answer: Fuck who did it. What I want to know is, who's the gimp?

question: He's alright.
answer: How do I know that? How about it, pretzel-man? What's your story?

question: Who are you?
answer: Agent Jack Baer, F.B.I. How many dead?

question: Fifteen so far. We're still pulling some bodies out of the water. Looking for anyone in particular?
answer: f don't want any of the bodies taken away until I've had a chance to go over this, understood?

question: I have to clear the scene. I've got word direct from the Chief
answer: Yes, the chief. Spooky stuff. Any survivors?

question: Two. There's a guy in county hospital, but he's in a coma. The D.A. has the other guy - A cripple - from New York I think. Listen, the Chief said -
answer: Excuse me.

question: No provisions, nothing. My clients testimony for his immunity.
answer: May-I be frank, Counselor? I suspect your political power as much as I respect it. I don't know why Mr. Kint has so many faceless allies in City Hall, and I don't care. The embarrassment he helped cause the city of New York will not happen here.

question: Immunity.
answer: Counselor, I will prosecute your client.

question: Then prosecute. I will be very impressed to see if the District Attorney manages to bring in twenty-seven simultaneous counts of murder against one man with cerebral palsy. I would think a man with your job would agree with these alleged "faceless people in City Hall" you mention.
answer: I'11 take my chances then. I'11 feel safer without a job if a man like Mr. Kint is behind bars.

question: Mr. Kint will plead guilty to weapons possession.
answer: You're joking.

question: Weapons. Misdemeanor one.
answer: Counselor, you're insulting me.

question: What do you mean I can't see him?
answer: The D.A. came down here last night ready to arraign before they even moved him to county. Kint's lawyer comes in and five minutes later, the D.A. comes out looking like he'd been bitch-slapped by the boogey man. They took his statement and cut him a deal.

question: Did they charge him with anything?
answer: Weapons. Misdemeanor two.

question: No, no, no, no, no.
answer: If it was a dope deal, where's the dope, if it was a hit, who called it in?

question: And I am sure you have a host of wild + theories to answer these questions.
answer: You know damn well what I think.

question: That's crazy, Dave and it doesn't matter. He has total immunity and his story checks out. He doesn't know what you want to know.
answer: I don't think he does. Not exactly, but there's a lot more to his story. I want to know why twenty-seven men died on that pier for what looks to be ninety-one million dollars worth of dope that wasn't there. Above all, I want to be sure that Dean Keaton is dead. Two hours. Just until he makes bail.

question: Yes. Joel, it's Baer. I'm down at L.A. county. The guy they pulled out of the harbor is ARKOSH Kovash... Yes, I'm sure... No, he's all fucked up... What? I can't hear you. Shut up, Hugo, I'm on the phone. Yes... No... Not until I put someone on him. Listen, I need you to send me someone who can speak Hungarian. He's awake and talking like a Thai hooker... How should I know? Get me someone who can talk to him -
answer: Keyser - Soze.

question: What?
answer: Keyser - Soze.

question: Verbal, you know we're trying to help you.
answer: Sure. And I appreciate that. And I want to help you, Agent Kujan. I like cops. I would have liked to have been a Fed myself but my C.P. was -

question: Verbal, I know you know something. I know you're not telling us everything.
answer: I told the D.A. everything I know.

question: I know you liked Keaton I know you think he was a good man.
answer: I know he was good.

question: He was a corrupt cop, Verbal.
answer: Sure. Fifteen years ago, but he was a good thief Anyway, the cops wouldn't let him go legit.

question: Keaton was a piece of shit.
answer: You trying to get a rise out of me, Agent Kujan?

question: I just want to hear your story.
answer: It's right here.

question: According to your statement you are a short-con operator. Run of the mill seams. Everything you do, you learned from somebody else.
answer: That's been suppressed. Anything in there is inadmissible.

question: Oh, I know. Sweet deal you have. Total immunity .
answer: Well I do have the weapons charge. I'm looking at six whole months hard time.

question: You know a dealer named Ruby Deemer, Verbal?
answer: You know a religious guy named John Paul?

question: You know Ruby is in Attica?
answer: He didn't have my lawyer.

question: I know Ruby. He's very big on respect. Likes me very much. Now I know your testimony was sealed. Ruby is well connected. He still has people running errands for him. What do you think he'd say if he found out you dropped his name to the D.A.?
answer: There's nothing in there about Ruby.

question: I'11 be sure to mention that to him. The first thing I learned on the job, know what it was? How to spot a murderer. Let's say you arrest three guys for the same killing. Put them all in jail overnight. The next morning, whoever is sleeping is your man. If you're guilty, you know you're caught, you get some rest - let your guard down, you follow?
answer: No.

question: I'11 get right to the point. I'm smarter than you. I'11 find out what I want to know and I'11 get it from you whether you like it or not.
answer: I'm not a rat. Ahhh. Back when I was picking beans in Guatemala we used to make fresh coffee. Right off the trees I mean. That was good. This is shit, but hey...

question: ...and the desk Sergeant is actually trying to tell me he can't release you? Can you believe that? You weren't even charged. New York police - Jesus. I want to take pictures of your face to bring to the D.A. first thing in the morning.
answer: Just forget about it.

question: Absolutely not. I'11 have this thing in front of a grand jury by Monday.
answer: Edie, please. I don't want to hear this right now. What did Renault and Fortier say?

question: They want more time to think about investing.
answer: Goddamnit.

question: They just said they wanted time.
answer: Time for what, Edie? Time to look into me a little more, that's what. No matter how well you cover my tracks now, they'll find out who I am.

question: Give me some credit. I got you this far, let's go to the grand jury. This is never going to stop if we -
answer: No. It's never going to stop, period. It won't take more than a week before every investor in this city is walking away from us. It's finished. I'm finished.

question: Don't give up on me now, Dean.
answer: They'll never stop.

question: I love you.
answer: They ruined me tonight.

question: Dean, I love you. Do you hear me? Let's just go to my place. We'll worry about this tomorrow.
answer: Huh?

question: Come home with me, please. Dean? Come home, Dean.
answer: Alright. What are you doing here'! How did you find me?

question: A glass of water would be nice.
answer: What the hell do you want?

question: I wanted to talk to you. The other guys -
answer: I did you a favor by standing up for you last night, but don't think we're friends. I'm sorry, but I have other things -

question: A hijacker like Dean, here? Or something more creative?
answer: That's enough, Edie.

question: I don't know what you came here for, but we won't have any part of it.
answer: Edie, please.

question: I've spent the last year of my life putting his back together again - I won't have you come in here and - What makes you think - GET OUT. GET OUT OF m HOME. HOW DARE YOU COME HERE? Don't touch me. Just don't,
answer: Get out.

question: Get out.
answer: If you'll just let me - Don't hurt me.

question: Hurt you, you sonofabitch? I could kill you.
answer: They're going to hit the Taxi Service. New York's Finest Taxi Service.

question: They - That's bullshit. They don't operate anymore.
answer: McManus has a friend in the Fourteenth Precinct. They're coming out for one job - Thursday. They're picking up a guy smuggling emeralds out of South America. Fenster and McManus have a fence set to take the stuff.

question: What fence? Who?
answer: Some guy in California. His name is Redfoot.

question: Never heard of him.
answer: You have to come.

question: What's with you? What do you care whether I come or not?
answer: They - They don't know me. You do. They won't take me unless you go. Look at me. I need this.

question: Tough break.
answer: Don't tell me you don't need this. Is this your place? They're never going to stop with us, you know that. This way we hit the cops where it hurts and get well in the mean time. As clean as you could ever get, they'll never let you go now.

question: You watch your mouth.
answer: Okay, okay. You say it's the real thing? That's cool.

question: I apologize.
answer: I was out of line.

question: You okay?
answer: I'11 be alright.

question: Well, I'm sorry.
answer: Forget it. I'11 probably shit blood tonight.

question: How are they going to do it?
answer: McManus wants to go in shooting. I said no way.

question: Fenster and Hockney?
answer: They're pretty pissed off. They'll do anything. Now I got a way to do it without killing anyone

question: Three million?
answer: Maybe more.

question: No killing?
answer: Not if we do it my way.

question: I swore I'd live above myself.
answer: New York's finest Taxi Service was not your normal taxi service. It was a ring of corrupt cops in the N.Y.P.D. that ran a high-profit racket, driving smugglers and drug dealers all over the city. For a few hundred dollars a mile, you got your own black and white and a police escort. They even had their own business cards. After a while, somebody started asking questions and the taxi service shut down. Ever since then, Internal Affairs had been waiting to catch them in the act. And that was how we started. McManus came to us with the job; Fenster got the vans; Hockney supplied the hardware; 'I came through with how to do it so no one got killed - but Keaton - Keaton put on the finishing touch. A little "Fuck you" from the five of us to the N.Y.P.D.

question: New York's finest Taxi Service was not your normal taxi service. It was a ring of corrupt cops in the N.Y.P.D. that ran a high-profit racket, driving smugglers and drug dealers all over the city. For a few hundred dollars a mile, you got your own black and white and a police escort. They even had their own business cards. After a while, somebody started asking questions and the taxi service shut down. Ever since then, Internal Affairs had been waiting to catch them in the act. And that was how we started. McManus came to us with the job; Fenster got the vans; Hockney supplied the hardware; 'I came through with how to do it so no one got killed - but Keaton - Keaton put on the finishing touch. A little "Fuck you" from the five of us to the N.Y.P.D.
answer: We db now, Jerk-off.

question: The papers got Keaton's call that day and were on the scene before the cops were. Strausz and Rizzi were indicted three days later. Within a few weeks, fifty more cops went down with them. It was beautiful. Everybody got it right in the ass, from the chief on down.
answer: When does the fence come?

question: In California?
answer: Hold the fuckin' phone. You and Fenster? No, no, no. I'm sure you can understand my hesitation.

question: We're gonna miss the plane. She'll understand.
answer: Heartwarming. Really, I feel weepy.

question: You wanted to know what happened after the line-up, I'm telling you.
answer: Oh come on, Verbal. Who do you think you're talking to? You really expect me to believe he retired? For a woman? Bullshit. He was using her.

question: He loved her.
answer: Sure. And I'm supposed to believe that hitting the Taxi Service wasn't his idea

question: That was all Fenster and McManus.
answer: Come on. Keaton was a cop for four years. Who else would know the Taxi Service

question: You keep trying to lay this whole ride on t Keaton. It wasn't like that. Sure he knew, but Edie had him all turned around. r I'm telling you straight, I swear. +
answer: Let me tell you something. I know Dean Keaton. I've been investigating him for three years. The guy I know is a cold- + blooded bastard. L.A.P.D. indicted him on three counts of murder before he was kicked off the force, so don't sell me the hooker with the heart of gold. +

question: You got him wrong.
answer: Do I? Keaton was under indictment a total + of seven times when he was on the force. + In every case, witnesses either reversed + their testimony to the grand jury or died + before they could testify. When they t finally did nail him for fraud, he spent + five years in Sing Sing. He killed three prisoners inside - one with a knife in the tailbone while he strangled him to death. Of course I can't prove this but I can't prove the best part either. Dean Keaton was dead. Did you know that? r He died in a fire two years ago during an investigation into the murder of a witness who was going to testify against him. Two people saw Keaton enter a warehouse he owned just before it went He was dead just long enough for a murder rap to blow over, then he had lunch.

question: I don't know about that.
answer: I don't think you do. But you say you saw Keaton die. I think you're covering his ass and he's still out there somewhere. I think he was behind that whole circus in the harbor. My bet is he's using you because you're stupid and you think he's your friend. You tell me he's dead, so be it. I want to make sure he's dead before I go back to New York.

question: He wasn't behind anything. It was the lawyer.
answer: What lawyer? What lawyer, Verbal?

question: Back when I was in that barber shop quartet in Skokie, Illinois I used to have
answer: You think I don't know you held out on the D.A.? What did you leave out of that testimony? I can be on the phone to Ruby Deemer in ten minutes.

question: The D.A. gave me immunity.
answer: NOT FROM ME, YOU PIECE OF SHIT. THERE IS NO IMMUNITY FROM ME. You atone with me or the world you live in becomes the hell you fear in the back of your tiny mind. Every criminal I have put in prison,

question: There was a lawyer. Kobayashi.
answer: Is he the one that killed Keaton?

question: No. But I'm sure Keaton's dead.
answer: Convince me. Tell me every last detail.

question: <<My name is Bodi. How are you'>>
answer: <<How am 17 You are as stupid as that one, but at least I can talk to you.>>

question: <<You'll be alright. He is from the F.B.I. He is here to help you. He wants to know what happened in the harbor.>>
answer: <<We were there to buy a man and take him back to Hungary.>>

question: You got it?
answer: Snazzy dresser this guy.

question: You must be Keaton. The man with the plan. Are you guys interested in more work?
answer: We're on vacation.

question: Two bodyguards. Pretty good. I'd expect nothing less. Take your time. Enjoy L.A.
answer: A friend of mine in New York tells me you knew Spook Hollis.

question: I hear you did time with old Spook. Yeah, he was a good egg. I used to run a lot of dope for him. Fuckin' shame he got shivved.
answer: I shivved him. Better you hear it from me now than somebody else later.

question: Business or personal?
answer: A little of both.

question: Ain't it a crime? Call if you're interested.
answer: One job, that was the deal. This is bullshit.

question: Move. Son of a bitch. What are you doing? We did it your way. Now I'11 deal with him. I'm going to deal with him.
answer: Get a grip. I didn't know.

question: You didn't know.
answer: The job got thrown to me by this lawyer.

question: Who is he?
answer: Some Limey. He's a middle-man for somebody. He doesn't say and I don't ask.

question: We want to meet him.
answer: He wants to meet you. He called last night and asked me to set it up. What do I tell him'

question: Tell him we'll meet.
answer: McManus, you're a real bad-ass, but get off my tip. Real shame about Saul getting whacked. Lot's of cops looking for the guys that did it. I'm sure They'll get around to asking me.

question: So this lawyer...
answer: Kobayashi.

question: Came from Redfoot.
answer: Right.

question: Jack. What are you doing here?
answer: I've been looking all over for you. You still after the coke that walked out of that blood bath in the harbor?

question: Yeah.
answer: You can stop looking. There was no coke. I've been in L.A. county with a guy they

question: There was ninety-one million -
answer: We know, but our man says no way on the dope. This Hungarian tells me the whole bunch was pulling stumps for Turkey the next' day. They had no time to negotiate that kind of product and no means to move it.

question: What was the money for?
answer: He didn't know. No one doing the deal knew except a few key people. This guy says they were real hush about it. Whatever it was it was highly sensitive.

question: I don't get it.
answer: They tell me you got the cripple from New York in there. He mention Keyser Soze

question: Who ?
answer: Bear with me here...

question: So I need to know if anyone can think of anybody. Somebody with power. Enough to possibly track us from New York.
answer: Mr. Keaton? I am Mr. Kobayashi. I've been asked by my employer to bring a proposal to you gentlemen. That must be Mr. Hockney. I recognize Mr. Fenster from his mug shot, as well as Mr. McManus. I can only assume that you are Mr. Kint. I believe you were the one who disposed of Saul. My employer sends his gratitude. A most unexpected benefit.

question: What can we do for you?
answer: My employer requires your services. One job. One day's work. Very dangerous. I don't expect all of you to live, but those who do will have ninety-one million dollars to divide any way they see fit.

question: Who's your boss?
answer: My employer wishes to remain anonymous.

question: Don't jerk me off. We all know what this is. You don't work with me if I work with you without knowing who I'm working for. Now let's cut the shit. Who's the man?
answer: I work for Keyser Sate.

question: Judging by the sudden change in mood, I am sure the rest of your associates can tell you, Mr. Kint. I have come with an offer directly from Mr. Soze. An order actually.
answer: An order.

question: In nineteen-eighty one, Mr. Keaton, you participated in the hijacking of a truck in Buffalo, New York. The cargo was raw steel. Steel that belonged to Mr. Soze and was destined for Pakistan to be used in a Nuclear reactor. A very profitable violation of U.N. Regulations. You had no way of knowing this, because the man shipping the steel was working for Mr. Sate without his knowledge. + Mr. Fenster and Mr. McManus hijacked a twin-prop cargo flight earlier this year out of Newark airport. The plane was carrying platinum and gold wiring. Also set for Pakistan. Two months ago, Mr. Hockney stole a truck carrying gun parts through Queens - - guns allegedly set to be destroyed by the state of New York. They were to be "lost" in a weigh station and routed to Belfast. Again, Mr. Sate using pawns who had no knowledge. Which brings us to Mr. Kint. Nine months ago, one of Mr. Soze less than intelligent couriers was taken in a complicated confidence seam by a cripple. He was relieved of sixty-two thousand dollars. Now - It has taken us some time to find you. Our intention was to approach you after your apprehension in New York.
answer: You set up the line-up.

question: Mr. Soze made a few calls, yes. You were not to be released until I came to see you. It seems Mr. Keaton's attorney, Ms. Finneran, was a bit too effective in expediting his release. Holding the rest of you became a moot point.
answer: What about Redfoot?

question: I came clean. I told it like it happened on the boat. So what if I left out how I got there? It's got so many holes in it, the D.A. would've told me to blow amnesty out my ass. So you got what you wanted out of me. Big fucking deal.
answer: And this is why you never told the D.A.

question: You tell me, Agent Kujan. If I told you the Loch Ness Monster hired me to hit the harbor, what would you say?
answer: Turn state's evidence. Take the stand on this and we'll hear it out.

question: I've got immunity now. What can you possibly offer me?
answer: If there is a Keyser Soze he'll be looking for you.

question: Where's your head, Agent Kujan? Where do you think the pressure's coming from? Keyser Soze - or whatever you want to call him - knows where I am right now. He's got the front burner under' your ass to let me go so he can scoop me up ten minutes later. Immunity was just to deal with you assholes. I got a whole new problem when I post bail.
answer: So why play into his hands? We can protect you.

question: <<It was smaller than that. Sharper.>>
answer: + The nose is sharper. Smaller too. + <<And what about the hair? You said something earlier about it.>>

question: <<It is longer than that. And not so dark. >>
answer: <<Are you sure?>>

question: <<Don't be stupid.>>
answer: He says the hair is longer and lighter.

question: That was how I ended up in a barber shop quartet in Skokie, Illinois.
answer: This is totally irrelevant.

question: Oh, but it's not. If I hadn't been nailed in Illinois for running a three card monte in between sets, I never would have took off for New York. I never would have met Keaton, see. That barber shop quartet was the reason for everything.
answer: Can we just get back to Kobayashi?

question: The quartet is part of the bit about Kobayashi. The quartet was in my file, along with every other thing I had done since high school, see? Aliases, middle- men. They knew me better than I did. They knew all of us.
answer: You're stalling, Verbal.

question: Give a guy a break, huh?
answer: What happened?

question: We woke up the next morning and Fenster was gone. He couldn't handle the idea of slumming for SOZE. He left a note wishing us good luck and took a chunk of the money we'd scraped together.
answer: Then what?

question: McManus was furious. He was talking about tracking him down and ripping his heart out and all sorts of shit. That night we got the call.
answer: What call?

question: The answer is no.
answer: Mr. Soze will be most -

question: Listen to me, cocksucker. There is no Keyser Sate. If you say his name again, I'11 kill you right here.
answer: A strange threat. I can only assume you're here to kill me anyway. Pity about Mr. Redfoot. Ahh, Mr. Hockney. Do join us.

question: We know you can get to us, and now you know we can get to you. I'm offering you the chance to call this off.
answer: Mr. So- My employer has made up his mind. He does not change it.

question: Neither do we.
answer: I believe you, Mr. McManus. I quite sincerely do. You would not have been chosen if you were not so capable, but I cannot make this decision. Whatever you can threaten me with is... ludicrous in comparison to what will be done to me if I am sorry, Mr. McManus. f implore you to believe me, Mr. Keaton. Mr. Soze is very real and very + determined.

question: We'll see.
answer: Before you do me in, you will let me finish my business with Ms. Finneran first, won't you?

question: What did you say?
answer: Edie Finneran. She is upstairs in my office for an extradition deposition. I requested she be put on the case personally. She flew out yesterday. No matter. Kill away, Mr. McManus.

question: You're lying.
answer: Am I? Ms. Finneran's escort in Los Angeles. Never leaves her for a moment. I thought you'd like to know she was in good hands. Get your rest, Gentlemen. The boat will be ready for you on Friday. If I see you or your friends before then, or fail to check in every half hour with that unpleasant looking man in there, Ms. Finneran will find herself the victim of a gruesome violation before she dies. As will your father, Mr. Hockney. and your Uncle Randall in Arizona, Mr. Kint. I might only castrate Mr. McManus' nephew, David. Do I make myself clear? I'11 take care of the dead men downstairs. We'll add them to the cost of Mr. Fenster. Now if you'll excuse me.

question: Everyone shut up. I'm ready. McManus, you better be set up in ten seconds. I want you to stay here. Understand? If we don't make it out, I want you to take the money and go.
answer: Keaton, I can't just -

question: I want you to find Edie. Both of you find some place safe. Tell her what happened - Everything. She knows people. She'll know what to do. If we can't get Kobayashi my way, she'll get him her way.
answer: What if I

question: And that's when you say in your statement that you saw... A man in a suit with a slim build. Tall.
answer: Wait a minute.

question: I don't have a minute. Are you saying it was Keyser Soze? You told the D.A. you didn't know who it was.
answer: I - there had to be dope there.

question: Don't shine me, Verbal. No more stalling. You know what I'm getting at.
answer: I don't. I don't know what you're talking about. I don't understand what you're saying. I saw Keaton get shot, I swear to you.

question: Then why didn't you help him?
answer: I WAS AFRAID, OKAY? Somehow, I was sure it was Keyser Soze at that point. I couldn't bring myself to raise my gun to him.

question: But Keaton...
answer: It was Keyser Soze, Agent Kujan. I mean the Devil himself. How do you shoot the Devil in the back? What if you miss?

question: Arturo Marquez. Ever hear of him?
answer: Wha- No.

question: He was a stool pigeon for the Justice Department. He swore out a statement to Federal Marshals that he had seen and could positively identify one Keyser Soze and had intimate knowledge of his business, including, but not exclusive to, drug trafficking and murder.
answer: I never heard of him.

question: His own people were selling him to a gang of Hungarians. Most likely the same Hungarians that Sate all but wiped out back in Turkey. The money wasn't there for dope. The Hungarians were going to buy the one guy that could finger Soze for them.
answer: I said I never heard of him.

question: But Keaton had. Edie Finneran was his extradition advisor. She knew who he was and what he knew.
answer: I don't

question: There were no drugs on that boat. It was a hit. A suicide mission to whack out the one man that could finger Keyser Soze so Sate had a few thieves put to it. Men he knew he could march into certain death.
answer: But how - wait. You're saying SOZE sent t us to kill someone?

question: I'm saying Keaton did. Verbal, he left you behind for a reason. If you all knew Soze could find you anywhere, why was he ready to send you off with the money when he could have used you to take the boat?
answer: He wanted me to live.

question: Why did he want you to live? A one-time dirty cop without a loyalty in the world finds it in his heart to save a worthless rat-cripple? No, sir. Why'
answer: Edie.

question: I don't buy that reform story for a minute. And even if I did, I certainly don't believe he would send you to protect her. So why?
answer: Because he was my friend.

question: No, Verbal. You weren't friends. Keaton didn't have friends. He saved you because he wanted it that way. It was his will.
answer: No...

question: Keaton was Keyser Soze The kind of guy who could wrangle the wills of men like Hockney and McManus. The kind of man who could engineer a police line-up from all his years of contacts in N.Y.P.D.
answer: NO, NO, NO, NO, NO.

question: They found her yesterday in a hotel in Pennsylvania. Shot twice in the head.
answer: Edie...

question: He used all of you to get him on that boat. He couldn't get on alone and he had to pull the trigger himself to make sure he got his man. The one man that could identify him.
answer: This is all bullshit.

question: He left you to stay behind and tell us he was dead. You saw him die, right? Or did you? You had to hide when the first police cars showed up. You heard the shot, just before the fire but you didn't see him die.
answer: I knew him. He would never -

question: He programmed you to tell us just what he wanted you to. Customs has been
answer: BUT WHY ME? WHY NOT HOCKNEY OR FENSTER OR McMANUS? I'm a cripple. I'm stupid. Why me?

question: Because you're a cripple, Verbal. Because you're stupid. Because you were weaker than them. Because you couldn't see far enough into him to know the truth. If he's dead, Verbal - if what you say is true, then it won't matter. It was his idea to hit the Taxi Service in New York, wasn't it? Tell me the truth.
answer: It was all Keaton. We followed him from the beginning. I didn't know. I saw him die. I believe he's dead. Christ

question: Why lie about everything else, then?
answer: You know what it's like, Agent Kujan, to know you'll never be good? Not good like you. You got good all fucked around. I mean a stand up guy. I grew up knowing I was never going to be good at anything 'cause I was a cripple. Shit, I wasn't

question: You're not safe on your own.
answer: You think he's..?

question: Is he Keyser Soze I don't know, Verbal. It seems to me that Keyser Sate is a shield. Like you said, a spook story, but I know Keaton - and someone out there is pulling strings for you. Stay here and let us protect you.
answer: I'm not bait. No way. I post today.

question: You posted twenty minutes ago. Captain Leo wants you out of here a.s.a.p., unless you turn state's.
answer: I'11 take my chances, thank you. It's tougher to buy the cheapest bag-man than it is to buy a cop.

question: Where are you going to go, Verbal? You gonna run? Turn states evidence. You might never see trial. If somebody wants to get you, you know They'll get you out there.
answer: Maybe so, but I'm no rat, Agent Kujan. You tricked me, that's all. I won't keep my mouth shut 'cause I'm scared. I'11 keep it shut 'cause I let Keaton down by getting caught - Edie Finneran too. And if they kill me, it's Fuckin' cops.

question: You still don't know shit.
answer: I know what I wanted to know about Keaton.

question: Which is shit.
answer: No matter. He'll have to know how close we came.

question: Keyser Sate or not, if Keaton's alive he'll never come up again.
answer: I'11 find him.

question: Waste of time.
answer: A rumor is not a rumor that doesn't die.

question: What?
answer: Nothing. Something I - forget it. Man, you're a fucking slob.

question: Yeah. It's got it's own system though. It all makes sense when you look at it right. You just have to step back from
